p: Many people around the world rely on traditional healthcare systems involving medicinal plants, which are often sold at open-air markets [ 1– 5]. This is also the case in Brazil, where a great variety of medicinal plants are still traded at open-air markets [ 6– 8]. These markets are hosted and visited by Brazilians and tourists from various cultural backgrounds. This cultural diversity is reflected in the number of available plant species and their uses [ 9]. It is easy to establish which medicinal plants are popular in the region through market surveys, as markets give an overview of local demand [ 10].
